revision.comment: Added information regarding the real name of Lizzie van Zyl, her mother and father's name and the reason she was put on the lowest rations (because she was classified as an undesirable).
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Lizzie van Zyl | image = LizzieVanZyl.jpg | imagesize = 225 px | caption = Lizzie van Zyl | birth_name = Elizabeth Cecilia van Zyl | birth_date = 22 April 1894 | birth_place = [[Boer Republics|Orange Free State Republic]] | death_date = 9 May 1901 (7 years old) | death_place = [[Bloemfontein]], Orange Free State Republic | death_cause = Typhoid Fever | burial_place = Unknown | nationality = South African | mother = Elizabeth Cecilia Van Zyl | father = Hermanus Egbert Pieter Van Zyl| }}
'''Lizzie van Zyl''' (22 April 1894 – 9 May 1901)<ref name="Bloemfontein">{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.uct.ac.za/mss/bccd/Histories/Bloemfontein/|title=British Concentration Camps of the South African War 1900–1902: Bloemfontein|publisher=[[University of Cape Town]]|accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="van Heyningen">{{cite journal|last=van Heyningen|first=Elizabeth|title=A tool for modernisation? The Boer concentration camps of the South African War, 1900–1902|journal=South African Journal of Science|volume=106|issue=5–6|date=8 June 2010|url=http://reference.sabinet.co.za/webx/access/electronic_journals/sajsci/sajsci_v106_n5_6_a17.pdf |accessdate= 13 September 2016}}</ref><ref>'''Title:''' SRC 07, '''Type:''' Correspondence, '''Location:''' VAB, '''Reference No.:''' 07, '''Dates:''' May 1901, '''Notes:''' RC1918, Deaths in camps, week ending 14/5/1901</ref><ref>'''Title:''' RS 30 ORC DL, '''Type:''' Death lists, '''Location:''' National Archives, Pretoria, '''Reference No.:''' RS 30, '''Origin:''' Goldman, Notes: p.353</ref><ref>'''Title:''' Government Gazette of the Orange River Colony, '''Location: Notes:'''17/5/1901, p.194</ref><ref name=":1">'''Title:''' SRC 71 Bloemfontein CR, '''Type:''' Camp register, '''Location:''' Free State Archives Repository, '''Reference No.:''' SRC 71, '''Notes:''' p.20</ref> was a South African child inmate of the [[Bloemfontein]] [[British concentration camps|concentration camp]] who was starved and ultimately died from [[typhoid fever]] during the [[Second Boer War]].<ref name="Bloemfontein"/><ref name="van Heyningen"/><ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last=Godby|first=Michael|date=2010|title=Confronting Horror: Emily Hobhouse and the Concentration Camp Photographs of the South African War|url=http://reference.sabinet.co.za/webx/access/journal_archive/02590190/617.pdf|journal=Department of Historical Studies|volume=University of Cape Town|issue=|doi=|pmid=|access-date=25 August 2016|via=}}</ref>
==Background==
The British incarcerated her and her mother (Elizabeth Cecilia van Zyl)<ref name=":1" /> in a concentration camp following the refusal of her father, Hermanus Egbert Pieter van Zyl<ref name=":1" />, a [[Boer]] Commando combatant, to surrender. Because of her father's refusal to surrender, Lizzie and her mother were labled as 'undesirables', and placed on the lowest food rations. Activist [[Emily Hobhouse]] used her death as an example of the hardships the Boer women and children faced in the British concentration camps during the war. She describes Lizzie as "a frail, weak little child in desperate need of good care", who was placed on the lowest rations and, after a month, was moved to the new hospital about {{convert|50|km|mi|abbr=off}} away from the concentration camp, suffering from starvation. Initially the publishers of Hobhouse's reports refused to publish the photograph.<ref name=":0" />
According to Hobhouse, she was treated harshly in the hospital. Unable to speak English, she was labelled an "idiot" by an English-speaking doctor and her nurses, who were unable to understand her. One day she started calling for her mother; a lady went over to comfort her, but "was brusquely interrupted by one of the nurses who told her not to interfere with the child as she was a nuisance." Lizzie died in 1901 at seven years of age.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boer.co.za/boerwar/hellkamp.htm|title=The Concentration Camps|publisher=Boer.co.za|date=21 May 1995|accessdate=3 June 2013}}</ref>
==Photo==
The photo of the emaciated van Zyl reportedly was passed from British author [[Arthur Conan Doyle]], who served as a volunteer doctor during the Boer War, to [[Joseph Chamberlain]].<ref name="lewis">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbctransgenerational.com/articles.html |title=Lizzy van Zyl |author=Hélène Opperman Lewis |accessdate=25 February 2015 }}</ref> Both Doyle and Chamberlain were proponents of the Boer Wars; Doyle wrote a short work ''The War in South Africa: Its Cause and Conduct'', that justified the war.
The photo was used as [[propaganda]], author Hélène Opperman Lewis states, to convince the British public that Boer children were neglected by their parents. The image was released with the detail that it was taken when van Zyl and her mother entered the camp. Chamberlain was quoted in ''[[The Times]]'' on 5 March 1902, saying that Lizzie's mother was prosecuted for mistreatment.<ref name="lewis"/>
Hobhouse investigated the case and was unable to find any evidence of the case or prosecution of Lizzie's mother. She located the photographer, a man named Mr. de Klerk (also a camp inmate at the time),<ref name=":0" /> who confirmed that the photograph was taken two months after Lizzie had arrived at the camp.<ref name="lewis"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Van Zyl, Lizzie}} [[Category:1894 births]] [[Category:1901 deaths]] [[Category:Afrikaner people]] [[Category:Prisoners who died in British military detention]] [[Category:Date of birth unknown]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:Deaths from typhoid fever]] [[Category:South African children]] [[Category:Second Boer War casualties]] [[Category:People from Orange Free State]] [[Category:Deaths by starvation]]

{{Infobox character | name = Luke the Dog | image = Luke_the_Dog,_1913-1926.jpg | caption = Luke (1913-1926)
in the Buster Keaton short
''[[The Scarecrow (1920 film)|The Scarecrow]]'', 1920 | first = 1914 | last = 1920 | portrayer = | nickname = | alias = | species = Dog
(Staffordshire Bull Terrier) | gender = Male }} '''Luke the Dog''' (1913-1926) was a [[Staffordshire Bull Terrier]] that performed as a recurring character in American silent comedy [[Short film|shorts]] between 1914 and 1920. He was also the personal pet of actress [[Minta Durfee]] and her husband, the comedian and director [[Roscoe Arbuckle|Roscoe "Fatty" Arbuckle]].Admin. (2012). [http://dogactors.com/2012/luke-the-pitbull/ Luke the Pitbull",] December 26, 2012. Dog Actors: Dogs on the Big Screen; retrieved September 16, 2017.In the early 1900s, before the [[American Kennel Club]] officially recognized the types of dogs in the United States commonly referred to as "[[pit bulls]]", Luke's breed was identified as an Irish or English Staffordshire Bull Terrier. Although Luke never attained the stardom of the various dogs that portrayed [[Rin Tin Tin]], [[Pete the Pup]], or [[Lassie]], he accomplished stunts on camera that those later canine colleagues may have found difficult or impossible to duplicate. Luke for six years gained widespread popularity among movie audiences, appearing in [[Film reel|one-]] and [[Film reel|two-reelers]] for [[Keystone Studios]], Comique Film Company, and Joseph M. Schenck Productions.[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1832937/ "Luke the Dog",] [[Internet Movie Database]] (IMDb), a subsidiary of [[Amazon.com]], Seattle, Washington; retrieved September 16, 2017. The bull terrier shared screen time not only with Arbuckle and Durfee but also with other stars and top supporting players of the silent era, including [[Mabel Normand]], [[Buster Keaton]], [[Al St. John]], [[Molly Malone (actress)|Molly Malone]], [[Joe Roberts]], [[Betty Compson]], and [[Edgar Kennedy]]. ==Early life== Luke the Dog was born in late 1913, reportedly at the home of film director [[Wilfred Lucas]] in [[Los Angeles, California]]. It was there where Minta Durfee and Roscoe Arbuckle were said to have acquired Luke as a six-week-old puppy. Several sources about the dog's early life state that Director Lucas gave the puppy to Minta in lieu of extra money or hazard pay she had earned for performing a dangerous stunt while filming.Kelly, Kate. [http://americacomesalive.com/2015/07/07/roscoe-fatty-arbuckles-dog-luke/ "Roscoe (Fatty) Arbuckle’s Dog, Luke",] America Comes Alive! New York; retrieved September 15, 2017. Some of those same sources also state that Minta and Roscoe even named their new pet after the tight-fisted director, dubbing him Luke as a familiar form of "Lucas" The cited timing of the dog's birth in the latter part of 1913 seems consistent with Luke's physical appearance in his film debut in the short ''[[Lover's Luck]]'', released in mid-September 1914 and likely completed in August that year. In the "[[Film reel|one-reeler]]", which features both Roscoe and Minta, Luke can be seen in the background in several scenes, tethered next to his doghouse. Luke's size in the short shows a dog of his breed nearing maturity.[https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=rZm0hdDqQTM "Lover's Luck (1914) Al St. John - Roscoe Arbuckle",] posted by Al St. John Official, YouTube; retrieved September 17, 2017. ==Film career== While Luke was originally given to Minta Durfee, Roscoe Arbuckle quickly became the dominant figure in the dog's daily life, for it was "Fatty" who invested the most time training the animal to do tricks."Lea" (2017). [https://silentology.wordpress.com/2017/07/20/a-salute-to-luke-the-dog/Luke "A Salute to Luke the Dog",] Silent-ology, July 17, 2017; retrieved September 16, 2017. Following his debut as a background pooch in ''Lover's Luck'', Luke worked in no fewer than a dozen more shorts released between January 1915 and December 1920.[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1832937/ "Luke the Dog",] IMDb; retrieved September 15, 2017. Luke next appears in ''[[Mabel and Fatty's Wash Day]]''. He has one very brief scene in that 1915 one-reeler, but at least the young dog is no longer relegated to the background. In the scene he quietly sits on a bench and receives a few affectionate pats from [[Mabel Normand]] as she goes into her backyard to hang laundry. In Luke's third film, ''[[Fatty's Faithful Fido]]'', released just two months after ''Mabel and Fatty's Wash Day'', he is finally allowed to display the success of his training and his remarkable athleticism.Ben Mankiewicz, [https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=ClDoHUCvrYw "shorts featuring dogs tcm intro, middle, outro",] Turner Classic Movies (TCM), posted by tcmfanatic. Available for viewing on YouTube; retrieved September 15, 2017. [[File:Luke_and_St._John,_Fatty's_Faithful_Fido,_1915.jpg|thumb|left|Luke catches [[Al St. John]] on a rooftop and refuses to release him in ''Fatty's Faithful Fido'', 1915.]]Luke performs a series of stunts in ''[[Fatty's Faithful Fido]]'' that are among the most impressive of his career. He gives chase to fellow cast member [[Al St. John]], who in the one-reeler plays Fatty's rival for the attention of a young woman portrayed by Minta. After repeated confrontations with his competitor, Fatty sics Luke on him. St. John's character panics and flees, but he cannot get away from the dog no matter what he does.[https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=EfohcqwCilg ""Fatty's Faithful Fido" -- Keystone Comedy (March 20, 1915)",] posted by Matt Barry, YouTube; retrieved September 15, 2017. Luke during the chase climbs a tall ladder propped against a wall, missteps and plunges off a building's roof, recovers, crosses another ladder between rooftops, jumps from one roof to another, grabs the coat of Fatty's rival in his teeth and tears it off his body, and then grabs the desperate man's necktie and starts choking him. St. John finally manages to escape but only when Luke is distracted by a passing cat. Soon, though, the dog resumes tracking his two-legged quarry. Later in the day Luke finally finds St. John at a community dance and charges into the event after him. The film ends with the dog, St. John, and Fatty falling through a hole in the floor and landing together in a large laundry tub of water. Luke has his longest screen time in a single film in ''[[Fatty's Plucky Pup]]'', also released in 1915.[https://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/552780/Fatty-s-Plucky-Pup/articles.html ''Fatty's Plucky Pup'',] Turner Classic Movies (TCM), [[Turner Broadcasting System]], a subsidiary of Time Warner, New York, N.Y.; retrieved September 20, 2017. He performs in almost every scene of the 26-minute two-reeler.[https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=v8bdWalp2Yk "Roscoe 'Fatty' Arbuckle~Fatty's Plucky Pup~1915 Keystone Film/Fotoplayer Soundtrack",] YouTube; retrieved September 20, 2017. In the short's first part, Luke proves to be an elusive terror for two [[dogcatcher]]s trying to capture him with large nets; and in its second part he rescues Fatty's girlfriend Lizzie from a pair of crooks, who kidnap her with the help of the same two dogcatchers. The "plucky pup" tracks the crooks; turns the tables on the dogcatchers by becoming their pursuer; and finally leads Fatty to save Lizzie in the nick of time, which also leads a carload of bumbling [[Keystone Cops]] to arrest the evil foursome. One of the interesting visual effects used in ''Fatty's Plucky Pup'' relied on the use of a [[treadmill]] in combination with the [[carousel]]-like "[[cyclorama]]" often used by cameramen at Keystone Studios' facilities in [[Edendale, Los Angeles, California|Edendale, California]].[https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=FiZiLXDfgas "Mack Sennett's Cyclorama on Glendale Blvd @ Effie",] posted by ValleySpringLaneHC, YouTube; a film clip showing the cyclorama (around 1915) operating at [[Mack Sennett]]'s Keystone Studios; retrieved September 20, 2017. There are sequences in the short that show Luke in close-up and running at breakneck speed through the countryside. The dog in reality is running on a treadmill positioned between a stationary camera and the cyclorama's rotating platform that has background scenery painted on a huge central cylinder. The cyclorama, which can be seen in operation at Keystone in a surviving period film clip, creates an effective but cartoonish simulation that Luke is dashing across the landscape.The top rotational speed of the cyclorama could not match the top running speed of Luke for filming by a stationary camera. Given the speed that the dog demonstrated on film, a treadmill was likely positioned in front of the cyclorama to produce the noted visual effect, including the sequence of Fatty cycling past Luke.In a later short, ''The Butcher Boy'' in 1917, Luke is shown running on a treadmill in a segment titled [https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=O0AD8___Aq4 "A job for Luke".] YouTube; retrieved September 22, 2017.[[File:The_Cook,_1918,_with_Arbuckle,_Luke,_and_Keaton.jpg|thumb|right|Roscoe "Fatty" Arbuckle, Luke, and [[Buster Keaton]] in ''The Cook'', 1918]] [[File:Fatty and Mabel Adrift 1916.jpg|thumb|left|Luke's popularity with audiences had risen to a point by 1916 that the stunt dog was included on a theater poster promoting the Keystone short ''Fatty and Mabel Adrift''.]] By 1916, Luke began to demonstrate that his athletic abilities were not limited to racing on the ground and vaulting through the air; he was equally proficient in water. Playing Arbuckle's faithful companion again in the two-reeler ''[[Fatty and Mabel Adrift]]'', Luke chases Fatty's frequent nemesis, Al St. John, into the ocean, not hesitating to dive into the surf and pursue the villain well past the breaking waves and into deeper water. Later in the film, Luke swims beachward to get help for Fatty and Mabel, whose honeymoon seaside cottage has been set adrift and is sinking.[https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=lLidW6gKRVk "''Fatty and Mabel Adrift'' (1916)",] posted by "A cinema history" and available for free viewing by the general public on YouTube; retrieved September 15, 2017. Following the completion of ''Fatty and Mabel Adrift'', Arbuckle left Keystone Studios to make films independently. Luke, of course, followed Roscoe and continued to appear in such films as ''[[The Butcher Boy (1917 film)|The Butcher Boy]]'' (1917), ''[[The Cook]]'' (1918), and ''[[The Hayseed]]'' (1919). In its review of ''The Butcher Boy'' in April 1917, the entertainment trade publication ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' complimented the film and observed, "The cast fits the star [Arbuckle], and not the least important member is 'Luke,' the bull terrier. It is a wonder."[https://archive.org/stream/variety46-1917-04#page/n123/mode/2up Film Reviews: ''The Butcher Boy'',] ''Variety'' (New York, N.Y.), April 20, 1917, page 24. [[Internet Archive]], San Francisco, California; retrieved September 22, 2017.[[File:Roscoe Arbuckle & Luke 1919.jpg|right|thumb|Arbuckle and Luke enjoying a ride together (''Moving Picture World'', January 25, 1919)]] Luke's reliability and experience as a performer earned him a top salary during his career of $150 a week, the equivalent of over $3,100 a week in the year 2017.Article about [http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/161697|0/Fatty-s-Faithful-Fido.html ''Fatty's Faithful Fido'',] TCM; retrieved September 18, 2017.[https://www.bls.gov/data/inflation_calculator.htm "CPI Inflation Calculator",] Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor, Washington, D.C.; retrieved September 18, 2017. His last two performances were in 1920, both uncredited: ''[[The Garage (1920 film)|The Garage]]'' with Arbuckle and Fatty's comedic protégé Buster Keaton and ''[[The Scarecrow (1920 film)|The Scarecrow]]'' with only Keaton. In those final shorts, a stockier, more muscular Luke continues to display his considerable prowess as a man-chaser. Keaton's character in ''The Scarecrow'' runs from what he mistakenly thinks is a [[Rabies|rabid]] dog, which he had seen "frothing" at the mouth. Actually, Luke had just eaten a cream pie and remnants of the cream remained around his snout. When Keaton dashes away, the "mad" dog relentlessly pursues him over brick walls, up ladders again, around the top of a building, over planks, through windows, down a garbage chute, and through haystacks.[https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=KWN5Em8wciI "The Scarecrow (1920) - Buster Keaton - Edward F. Cline",] posted by Change Before Going Productions. YouTube; retrieved September 18, 2017. ==Later years and death== [[File:The Scarecrow 1920.jpg|thumb|left|Luke with Keaton in the 1920 short ''The Scarecrow'', the dog's final film]]The talented canine continued to spend most of his time with Roscoe until Arbuckle and Minta separated in 1921 and finally divorced in 1925. Minta gained custody of Luke as part of the couple's separation agreement and divorce settlement, although Roscoe did have visitation rights to see him. That arrangement may explain why the veteran stunt dog did not appear again on screen after his work with Keaton in ''The Scarecrow'' in 1920. A [[Roscoe Arbuckle|scandal]] that rocked Arbuckle's personal and professional life in 1921 may have also affected Luke's career and be another reason for his apparent retirement from performing. The public closely identified Luke with Fatty, whose own acting career tragically ended as a result of the noted scandal.Rosenberg, Jennifer (2017). [https://www.thoughtco.com/fatty-arbuckle-scandal-1779625 "The 'Fatty' Arbuckle Scandal".] Thought.Co, updated article June 12, 2017; retrieved September 23, 2017. Arbuckle's films were effectively banned from theaters for a while, and some things even associated with the former star were shunned by moviegoers and the media as well.King, Gilbert (2011). [https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/the-skinny-on-the-fatty-arbuckle-trial-131228859/ "The Skinny on the Fatty Arbuckle Trial",] ''Smithsonian'' (Smithsonian.com), Washington, D.C., November 8, 2011; retrieved December 25, 2017. Whatever the reasons for Luke's absence from films after 1920, available records suggest that he lived the remaining years of his life with Minta. Luke died in 1926 in [[Los Angeles California|Los Angeles]] at age 13, in keeping with the average life expectancy of his breed.[http://dogtime.com/dog-breeds/staffordshire-bull-terrier#/slide/1 "Staffordshire Bull Terrier",] ''DogTime''; Dog Time Media, Inc., San Francisco, California; retrieved September 19, 2017. It is unknown where his remains were interred.Carrie-Anne (2005). [https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=11661818 "Luke the Dog",] online memorial 11661818 with brief history and photographs created September 1, 2005. [[Find a Grave]], subsidiary of [[Ancestry.com]], Lehi, Utah; retrieved September 19, 2017. ==Filmography== *''[[Lover's Luck]]'' (1914) *''[[Mabel and Fatty's Wash Day]]'' (1915) *''[[Fatty's New Role]]'' (1915) *''[[Fatty's Faithful Fido]]'' (1915) *''[[Fatty's Plucky Pup]]'' (1915) *''[[Fatty and Mabel Adrift]]'' (1916) *''[[The Butcher Boy (1917 film)|The Butcher Boy]]'' (1917) *''[[Coney Island (1917 film)|Coney Island]]'' (1917) *''[[The Cook]]'' (1918) *''[[The Sheriff]]'' (1918) *''[[The Hayseed]]'' (1919) *''[[The Garage (1920 film)|The Garage]]'' (1920) *''[[The Scarecrow (1920 film)|The Scarecrow]]'' (1920) == References and notes == {{Reflist|20em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{Find a Grave|11661818}} * {{IMDb name|1832937}} [[Category:1913 animal births]] [[Category:1926 animal deaths]] [[Category:Dog actors]]

{{Infobox comics character | image = Scorpion (Mac Gargan).jpg | caption = Mac Gargan as Scorpion. Art by [[Bret Blevins]]. | real_name = MacDonald "Mac" Gargan | publisher = [[Marvel Comics]] | debut = '''As Mac Gargan''':
''[[The Amazing Spider-Man]]'' #19 (December 1964)
'''As Scorpion''':
''Amazing Spider-Man'' #20 (January 1965)
'''As Venom''':
''[[The Sensational Spider-Man (vol. 2)|Marvel Knights Spider-Man]]'' #10 (March 2005)
'''As Spider-Man''':
''[[Dark Avengers]]'' #1 (March 2009) | creators = [[Stan Lee]]
[[Steve Ditko]] | alliances = [[Dark Avengers]]
[[Thunderbolts (comics)|Thunderbolts]]
[[Sinister Six]]
[[Sinister Six|Sinister Twelve]]
[[Masters of Evil]]
[[Alchemax]] | aliases = [[Scorpion (Marvel Comics)|Scorpion]], [[Venom (Marvel Comics character)|Venom]], [[Spider-Man]], "Kilgore Trout" | powers = '''As Scorpion''':
Superhuman strength, speed, agility, stamina, durability and reflexes
Precognitive Scorpion-Sense
Wears scorpion-like armor with a cybernetic tail that has projectile weapons
Ability to cling to most surfaces
'''As Venom and Spider-Man''':
